bioghist.p: Ernest Adolf Spiegel, neurologist, was born in Vienna, in 1895. He married Mona Spiegel-Adolf in 1925. Spiegel died in 1985. Spiegel received his M.D. from the University of Vienna in 1918. From 1924 to 1930, he was a docent in anatomy and the physiology of the nervous system at the University. In 1930, Spiegel joined the staff of Temple University in Philadelphia, becoming Professor of Experimental and Applied Neurology and head of the Department of Experimental Neurology. He edited Confinia Neurologica and Progress in Neurology and Psychiatry. In the 1960s, Spiegel and his wife both were associated with the National Parkinson Institute, investigating inexpensive treatments for the disease using dopamine. Ernest A. Spiegel was known for developing the use of guided electrodes into the brain to treat involuntary movements, intractable pain, emotional disorders, and brain tumors.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Ernest A. Spiegel. Materials include: correspondence with Rodney Goode about the manufacture of a stereotactic frame; correspondence with various physicians, including Dr. Russell Meyers; notes for articles; photographs of a stereotactic guide; copies of proceedings and abstracts from a symposium on Stereotactic Irradiation, 1979 and from the European Society for Stereotactic and Functional Neurosurgery; four letters to Spiegel from Richard Georg Plaschka, 1982-1983; outline and plans for a Cerebral Stereotactic Institute that was to have been built near the Temple Medical School from the early 1960s; several reprints and articles; copies of diplomas and academic credentials and translations of these documents; and several plaques and awards. The collection also includes photographs of procedures using stereotactic equipment (prints from x-rays and snapshots) and family photographs and cabinet cards.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
